The need for this compensation step can be understood via the lumped circuit model (Ref. 31). When the planes of the two steps coincide, the fringing capacitance between the shoulders of the outer and inner diameter steps create a region of low impedance at the transition (a shunt capacitance). Offsetting the planes of the steps slightly to create a third region of high impedance adds a series inductance which then compensates for the fringing capacitance. Without this compensation the fringing capacitance will cause a reflection from the transition region.

Dynamic link libraries, as the name suggests, are libraries of procedures that applications can link to and use at run time. They are useful to perform special actions that Visual Basic cannot perform directly. To use procedures of a DLL in a Visual Basic application, it is necessary to declare them in the Main.bas module of the project. Once the appropriate procedures declarations have been pasted into the code, the procedure can be used by the application such as any other visual basic procedure.
The Inp Procedure was used as an example in Jay Munro’s Writting DLLs and Controls in Assembly language at the August 1991 Microsoft Developers Conference.
It is available as a shareware on the Internet (for example, at ftp.area.fi.cnr.it/pub/mirror/win3/programr/vbasic/inpout.zip).

The synthesis of the block copolymers was performed by E. J. Kramer and co-workers, Dept. Materials Science and Engineering, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14850.

It turned out that the dipping time had no influence on the resulting structures. Recent experiments indicate, however, that the speed at which the samples are removed from the solution is a crucial parameter in the process. In the present experiments, the samples were removed from the solution at speeds around some mm∕sec. A detailed discussion of the dipping conditions on the resulting structures shall be published elsewhere (Ref. 6).

If the surface micelles formed on a homogeneous brush of PS-PVP, it would be expected that the PVP blocks in the brush would also be loaded with CdCl2, thereby leading to a homogeneous background in the TEM micrographs. However, carbon coated TEM grids have been used providing rather nonpolar substrates. In contrast to the situation faced on mica, on these surfaces brush formation is not expected underneath the surface micelles.

The issue of static versus zero-point dynamic Jahn–Teller distortions depends on the time scale. The EPR linewidth is proportional to the time integral of the correlation function 〈[SxT,Hanis](t)[Hanis,SxT](0)〉, where SxT denotes the x component of the total spin and Hanis is the anisotropic part of the Hamiltonian. If this correlation function decays at a rate that is rapid in comparison with the characteristic frequencies of the dynamic Jahn–Teller effect, then the distinction between the static and dynamic linewidth mechanisms disappears. Such would appear to be the case for the DE interaction in the manganites where the characteristic time scale of the correlation function is set by the hole bandwidth.

citation.unstructured_citation: The Sb consumption rate slowly decreases over a period of several seconds upon opening the In shutter and then saturates to a steady state value. Initial smaller Sb consumption might be a consequence of the strain in an InSb thin layer on GaSb. Thus, some of the In atoms are initially rejected. Strain relaxation in InSb, possibly via islanding, after 1–2 ML of growth eventually leads to steady state In incorporation. For fixed Sb flux and In flux, Sb consumption as a function of substrate temperature increases and then saturates as the substrate temperature decreases to below 400 °C, indicating a final unity In incorporation probability being reached.

For x-ray simulations, we construct one InSb-like interface as 0.5ML (∼1.62 Å) of InSb. Thus for the structure (InAs)8/(GaSb)8 having both InSb-like interfaces, numerically, it reads (GaAs)8/(InSb)0.5/(InAs)7/(InSb)0.5. The structure (GaAs)8/(InSb0.5As0.5)1/(InAs)6/(InSb0.5As0.5)1 gives a value of a⊥ of 6.110 Å for nonstrain relaxation. A similar construction of the interface is used for GaAs-like or mixed type interfaces.

The theoretical optimized Ge46 lattice constant is about 10.5 Å, while the experimental lattice constant of Sr8Ga16Ge30 is about 10.7 Å. The exact lattice constants of alloy type (Ge, Ga)46 clathrates may vary slightly with different guest species and Ga substitution ratio. LDA methods we used here underestimate the true lattice constants by about 1%–2%.

LDA methods are known for their underestimation of band gaps in semiconductors. Yet, it is believed that LDA describes the trends of the gap. Based on the fact that LDA underestimates the gap in Ge diamond phase by about 0.7 eV, we roughly estimate the true gap in semiconductor clathrates by adding 0.7 eV to the LDA calculated gap. For example, the LDA gives 1.21 eV for the band gap of Ge46, so we estimate the true gap as 1.9 eV.

Raman scattering intensities from framework (Ge/Ga) atoms and from guest (Rb/Sr) atoms are estimated separately. For framework atoms, the bond-polarizability parameters are: α1/αq=−2, and α25/αq=−0.75. The intensity from guests are estimated as α1/αq=0, and α25/αq=−0.25. The total scattering intensities are the weighted sum of framework scattering intensities (×1.0) and the guest scattering intensities (×0.2). The estimate of Raman intensities is only qualitative.
